Article.Abstract: A random peptide library of heptamers displayed on the surface of M13 bacteriophage was used to identify specific epitopes of antibodies in pooled sera of swine naturally infected by Nipah virus. The selected heptapeptides were aligned with protein sequences of Nipah virus and several putative epitopes were identified within the nucleocapsid protein. A total of 41 of 60 (68%) selected phage clones had inserts resembling a region with the sequence SNRTQGE, located at the C-terminal end (amino acids 503-509) of the nucleocapsid protein. The binding of antibodies in the swine and human antisera to the phage clone was inhibited by a synthetic peptide corresponding to this region. Epitopes identified by phage display are consistent with the predicted antigenic sites for the Nipah virus nucleocapsid protein. The selected phage clone used as a coating antigen discriminated swine and human Nipah virus sera-positive from sera-negative samples exhibiting characteristics, which might be attractive for diagnostic tests.
Article.ArticleTitle: Identification of epitopes in the nucleocapsid protein of Nipah virus using a linear phage-displayed random peptide library.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Microbiology, Faculty of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Antibodies, Viral(blood; metabolism); Antigens, Viral; Bacteriophage M13(chemistry; metabolism); Binding Sites, Antibody; Clone Cells; Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay; Epitope Mapping; Epitopes(blood; chemistry; immunology); Humans; Molecular Sequence Data; Nipah Virus(immunology); Nucleocapsid Proteins(chemistry; immunology); Oligopeptides(chemistry; genetics; immunology); Peptide Library; Swine

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Occurrence of infectious disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: All the swine anti-Nipah virus sera with known serum neutralizing test were obtained from Veterinary Research Institute (VRI), Malaysia.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope significantly inhibited the binding of swine anti-Nipah virus serum to immobilized phages bearing the mimic peptide SNPTQGH. The antisera also directly bound to the epitope.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Occurrence of infectious disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: The human anti-Nipah virus serum was a generous gift from K.B. Chua.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope significantly inhibited the binding of human anti-Nipah virus serum to immobilized phages bearing the mimic peptide SNPTQGH. The antisera also directly bound to the epitope.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Occurrence of infectious disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: The human anti-Nipah virus serum was a generous gift from K.B. Chua.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope did not inhibit the binding of human anti-Nipah virus serum to immobilized phages bearing the mimic peptide SIYAAEK.
